body: On first hearing, it simply did not make sense. How could Stationery and Toy, a cherished, packed daughter-and-pop store at 125 West 72nd Street, have lost almost all of its inventory during Hurricane Sandy? After all, the Upper West Side was barely discommoded by the storm. Most residents suffered from nothing much more serious than
title: CITY ROOM; A Hurricane Victim In an Unlikely Place

body:
MAPLETON is on New York City ’s street closures map. You’ll also find houses in Mapleton on real estate sites like Trulia and Streeteasy. There’s a Mapleton branch of the public library and a Mapleton public school, along with a bowling alley and a Kiwanis Club. But just where the heck is Mapleton, Brooklyn ?
 
If the
title: LIVING IN; When Is a Neighborhood a Sandwich?

body:
MAPLETON is on New York City ’s street closures map. You’ll also find houses in Mapleton on real estate sites like Trulia and Streeteasy. There’s a Mapleton branch of the public library and a Mapleton public school, along with a bowling alley and a Kiwanis Club. But just where the heck is Mapleton, Brooklyn ?

title: LIVING IN; When Is a Neighborhood a Sandwich?

body:
On the surface, Salvatore Costanzo’s home life seems fairly normal.
 
His spacious two-level apartment in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, is cozy and warm, shining spotlessly from floor to ceiling on a rainy fall morning. Mr. Costanzo sits in an armchair with his wife, Maria, and 11-year-old daughter, Barbara, at his side. Two well-fed cats
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Fighting Hidden Illness Whose Draining Effects Are Noticed Every Day

body: KEYES--Marion E.,age 96, died peacefully at her home in Flushing, NY on November 24th. Born in Brooklyn to Leo and Margaret Keyes, she graduated from Hunter College. Marion was a math teacher at Bay Ridge HS and Francis Lewis HS. She is survived by her brother William, brother-in-law John Shevlin and eight nieces and nephews. She was pre-deceased
title: Paid Notice: Deaths KEYES, MARION E.

body:
Eric McClure got to 19,268 blog posts. Enough. It was time, he decided, “to hang up my keyboard.” 
 
Eight years ago, after having sold an advertising business, he joined the convulsive battle over what would fall and what would rise on a plot of land in the heart of Brooklyn, 15 blocks from where he lived. Now he was spent.
title: Opponents of Atlantic Yards Are Exhausted by a Long, Losing Battle

body: KEYES--Marion E.,age 96, died peacefully at her home in Flushing, NY on November 24th. Born in Brooklyn to Leo and Margaret Keyes, she graduated from Hunter College. Marion was a math teacher at Bay Ridge HS and Francis Lewis HS. She is survived by her brother William, brother-in-law John Shevlin and eight nieces and nephews. She was pre-deceased
title: Paid Notice: Deaths KEYES, MARION E.

body: Brad Richards, the son of lobster fishers in Prince Edward Island, joined the Rangers just 17 months ago, but he is definitely a New Yorker now. In the days after Hurricane Sandy , he has been a frequent volunteer in hard-hit parts of the city, gutting flood-damaged homes in Queens and helping to organize a benefit hockey clinic on Staten Island.
title: A Ranger Rolls Up His Sleeves and Takes a Big Role in Hurricane Relief

body:
The search for a suspect in the recent deaths of three Brooklyn shopkeepers ended on Wednesday with the arrest of a clothing dealer whom Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly described as a “serial killer” intent on finding more victims. 
 
The arrest of the clothing dealer, Salvatore Perrone, 64, of Staten Island — who
title: Man Arrested in Deaths of 3 Brooklyn Merchants Is Called ‘Serial Killer’

body:
Opening

 
ANDANADA 141 The name refers to a grandstand in the bullfighting ring. When Alvaro Reinoso joined the partnership that owned Gastroarte after the chef Jesús Núñez left, he kept the graffiti-style bullfight mural that covered one wall. He has brought in Manuel Berganza, who was the executive chef at Sergi Arola
title: Off the Menu

body:
Detectives searching for a gunman believed to have killed three Brooklyn shopkeepers were interviewing a man on Tuesday evening who resembled a person caught on surveillance footage near the scene of the last murder, a police spokesman said.
 
Asked whether he was a suspect, the spokesman said, “We’re not labeling him
title: Police Interview Man in Connection With Brooklyn Merchant Killings

body:
The first killing took place days after the Fourth of July inside Valentino Fashion in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, where the proprietor was found shot in the neck.
 
The second, a month later, in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, occurred in a store called Amazing 99 Cent and Up Deals. The shopkeeper there was stabbed in the neck and shot in the head. Then
title: Same .22-Caliber Pistol Was Used to Kill Three Merchants in Brooklyn, Police Say

body: Surfers with shovels fanned out in the Rockaways in Queens, helping residents clear their homes of mud and sand. An army of cyclists strapped packages of toilet paper to their backs and rode into Belle Harbor, Queens. Children broke open piggy banks, bought batteries and brought them to the parking lot of the Aqueduct Racetrack and Resorts World
title: Volunteers Flock to Disaster Areas, Overwhelming City Relief Centers

body:
Arriving in Venice years ago, Robert Benchley, the New York journalist and wit, is said to have sent a mock-panicked telegram to his editor: “Streets flooded. Please advise.”
 
After the enormous storm last week, which genuinely panicked New York with its staggering and often fatal violence, residents here could certainly
title: Protecting the City, Before Next Time

author: E-mail: geovec@nytimes.com
body:
The right decision, to call off the New York City Marathon , was only 72 hours late. 
 
It could have and should have been made as soon as Sandy stopped bombarding the region, as soon as it became apparent that people had died, and that millions were in trouble. It is a grand day in a great city, but ultimately it is only a sports event.
title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES; Wisely Stepping Aside In a Bombarded City

body:
In the best of times, the Knicks made Nelson Ortiz weep.
 
It happened in 1994, when Pat Riley’s squad buckled in Game 7 of the Finals and lost the championship to the Houston Rockets. It happened again in 1999, when the eighth-seeded Knicks returned to the Finals, in fairy-tale fashion, only to get crushed by the San Antonio Spurs.
title: Fans in Brooklyn Have New Shoulder to Cry On

body:
New York City public schools will remain closed through the rest of the week, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Wednesday, creating an enormous scheduling headache for harried parents.
 
The mayor said he expected almost all schools to reopen on Monday. He acknowledged it was an “inconvenience for parents” for children to miss a
title: Storm Closes City Schools for a Week, the System’s Longest Suspension in Decades

body:
IN Brooklyn folklore, Bay Ridge remains the home of Tony Manero, the white-suited disco sensation played by John Travolta in “Saturday Night Fever.” 
 
But that was 1977. Today, the neighborhood is as visibly Arab-American as it was Brooklyn Italian back then. And on Saturday nights these days, the Lebanese restaurant Le Sajj
title: NEIGHBORHOOD JOINT | BAY RIDGE; Smoke, Dance And a Sliver Of Lebanon

body: Residents of Brooklyn have been called many things over the years, including hopeless nostalgists and, more recently, hipsters and arrivistes. But it has been a century or more since anyone really called people in Brooklyn ''islanders.'' Yes, the borough is on Long Island. Any map will confirm that fact. But while many in Brooklyn are thrilled to
title: A Team by Any Other Name May Be Less Confusing

author: E-mail: geovec@nytimes.com
body: Brooklyn giveth and Brooklyn taketh away. The borough that carried a victim's posture for half a century is now collecting sports franchises. At least Brooklyn is not spiriting away much of anything from the haunted house farther out on Long Island. Maybe the nickname of the team; maybe the orange and blue colors. But Brooklyn cannot carry away the
title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES; Islanders Leaving, the Glory Long Gone

author: E-mail: dwyer@nytimes.com; Twitter: @jimdwyernyt
body: At work in Cairo during the early 1980s, Steve Hindy found himself drinking beer that had been brewed at home by other American expatriates. They had picked up the skill living in parts of the Middle East where alcohol was banned. It was pretty good, and Mr. Hindy learned to make it himself when he and his family moved back to New York in 1984.
title: ABOUT NEW YORK; Expanding On a Brew Native To Brooklyn

body: The vast glass and marble lobby of the former Bear Stearns building at 383 Madison Avenue has seen its share of celebration and woe. Between the building's construction in 2001 and the bank's 2008 collapse, it was the scene of Christmas parties, executive functions, even an appearance by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. In 2008, employees stripped of
title: CITY ROOM; A Wedding Celebration Dispels a Building's Woe

body: Voters in Staten Island know plenty about Representative Michael G. Grimm , the embattled first-term Republican facing a barrage of questions about his fund-raising practices and business deals. The man trying to defeat him this fall, however, remains something of a mystery. Mark Murphy, the Democratic challenger in New York City's most
title: A Seat for the Taking, but First Seeking Traction

body: Voters in Staten Island know plenty about Representative Michael G. Grimm , the embattled first-term Republican facing a barrage of questions about his fund-raising practices and business deals. The man trying to defeat him this fall, however, remains something of a mystery. Mark Murphy, the Democratic challenger in New York City's most
title: A Seat for the Taking, but First Seeking Traction

body: Maybe it was the experience of growing up in a family with 12 children in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, that propelled Veronica M. White outdoors and fostered a passion for parkland. Shore Road Park, with its sweeping views of New York Bay and the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, became Ms. White's extended backyard. ''That's where I learned to play baseball and
title: New Parks Chief Is a Voice for Expansion

body: $9 MILLION 8300 Fourth Avenue (at 83rd Street) Bay Ridge, Brooklyn An investor has bought this 50,000-square-foot, six-story elevator building. The 1929 building has 68 apartments -- 29 studios, 22 alcove studios, 13 one-bedrooms and 4 two-bedrooms. Buyer: 8300 4th Avenue Management Corporation Seller: 8300 Fourth Avenue L.L.C. Brokers: Aaron
title: Recent Sale

body: DAVIS--Edmund Raphael, 86, of Bridgehampton, NY died Monday September 24, 2012 at Southampton Hospital in Southampton NY. Born April 8, 1926 in Brooklyn NY to Mary and Raphael Davis. He is survived by his wife of 44 years, Phyllis Burke Davis, a brother, Will Davis of Newtown, PA, a sister, Nancy Jean Davis of Brooklyn, NY, and numerous nieces and
title: Paid Notice: Deaths DAVIS, EDMUND RAPHAEL

body: Unlike many of the 30-somethings in the food business in Brooklyn, Louis Coluccio Jr. did not change careers and take up pickling or baking. His grandfather Domenico Coluccio started an Italian food importing and distribution business, D. Coluccio & Sons, in Bensonhurst some 50 years ago. Last year, Louis (shown above), 30, and his wife, Alison,
title: FOOD STUFF; Reinvention With the Family Name

body: CHATHAM, N.J. TICKER tape: it's an enduring image of Wall Street. The paper is gone but the digital tape runs on, across computer and television screens. Those stock quotations scurrying by on CNBC are, for many, the pulse of American capitalism. But Sal L. Arnuk doesn't really believe in the tape anymore -- at least not in the one most of us see.
title: In Search of a Market Speed Limit

body: TO find the head professional at the Marine Park Golf Course in Brooklyn, look for a flamboyant outfit of plaids and pastels, and follow the smoke. You will most likely spot him over on the driving range, enjoying a cigar, bantering with players and fixing swings. He is Hunter Watkins, 41, and he mastered golf by playing the guitar. A veteran of
title: CHARACTER STUDY; Guiding Golfers to Rock Their Shots

body: THIS morning, I grabbed a bowl from the cabinet, went outside and picked my breakfast of fresh figs . No, I'm not vacationing near the Mediterranean coast. Nor am I in California or the South. I'm at home in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, where the fig tree in my tiny garden is covered in ripening fruit. I've had the tree for 15 years, but when the
title: A GOOD APPETITE; Italy to Brooklyn, Fig by Fig

body: With its octagonal brick towers rising above the beach, the sprawling bathhouse at Jacob Riis Park in the Rockaways has, since opening in 1932, served as a monument to Art Deco design, grand public works and populist fun. Lately, however, it has become a symbol of something else: public frustration.Renovation work began in the 1990s on the
title: A Promise Unfulfilled at an Art Deco Bathhouse in the Rockaways

body: THE New York bar, like all complex professional societies, has every sort of specialty you can think of: white-shoe litigators, Mafia defenders, crusading Legal Aiders, corporate crisis managers, City Hall fixers, real estate closers and lowly filers of slip-and-fall lawsuits. Sal Strazzullo's specialty is that capricious class of person occupying
title: The Night-Life Lawyer

body: THE New York bar, like all complex professional societies, has every sort of specialty you can think of: white-shoe litigators, Mafia defenders, crusading Legal Aiders, corporate crisis managers, City Hall fixers, real estate closers and lowly filers of slip-and-fall lawsuits. Sal Strazzullo's specialty is that capricious class of person occupying
title: The Night-Life Lawyer

body: John Noerr and his 5-year-old son were chasing snakes in the Adirondacks last month when they stumbled on a grimy, expensive digital camera sitting in a foot of water in a stream.Mr. Noerr, a 39-year-old art teacher, took a screwdriver and pried open a flap that concealed the camera's memory card. He extracted the card, cleaned it off and put it in
title: CITY ROOM; After 3 Years in the Adirondacks, a Lost Camera Reveals Secrets to Its Home Far Away

body: The recent killings of two shopkeepers in south Brooklyn bore eerie similarities, though their deaths occurred nearly four weeks apart. Both were shot in the head or neck with what the police said were .22-caliber guns. Both were Egyptian immigrants around retirement age. And both sold their wares at addresses that contained the same numbers: two
title: Fatal Shootings of 2 Brooklyn Shopkeepers Unnerve Fellow Merchants

body: To hear residents in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn talk on Thursday afternoon, it was as if the sky were falling. The earth, at least, was definitely falling. A 30-foot-wide, 10-foot-deep crater of dirt and asphalt yawned on 79th Street between Fourth and Fifth Avenues after the street suddenly caved in on Wednesday afternoon, nearly taking one
title: At a Bay Ridge Sinkhole, Neighbors Reminisce

body: International VILLAGERS IN MEXICO TAKE PROTECTIVE MEASURES Residents of Cherán, a village in Mexico, say that they have been terrorized by paramilitary loggers, backed by drug gangs, who have devastated the surrounding forests. In response, the townspeople have established a simple but effective internal protection system. Page A4 A RELATIVELY
title: Inside the Times

body: It seemed that every parent in Park Slope was talking about it. A new bar was opening on the edge of the neighborhood and its owner had put out the word to local families: strollers welcome. This was big news among the stroller set in a Brooklyn neighborhood where relations between those with children and those without have often been testy. But
title: CITY ROOM; As Beer Garden Extends Welcome To Juice-Box Set, Some Barflies Jeer

body: SABRINA SEELIG seemed too young to die. Just 22, she lived in a railroad flat in Bushwick, a part of Brooklyn that at the time was cheap but not yet hip, with a roommate who worked at the Museum of Modern Art. Ms. Seelig worked as a waitress in bistros on the Lower East Side while writing a novel and studying classics at Hunter College. One night
title: The Short Life and Lonely Death of Sabrina Seelig

body: THE golden age of Brooklyn disco is not dead -- it's hiding in Tony Ferrante's closet in Gravesend. ''See, look at this; you tell me, who's got a shirt like this?'' he asked, rummaging through a rack of vintage shirts and pulling out a shiny silver number with collars wide enough to ski down. ''I do, that's who.'' Mr. Ferrante, 78, who is better
title: CHARACTER STUDY; He's Tony Disco to You

body: At 2 a.m., the shuttered streets of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, were mostly deserted. But inside a persimmon-colored cafe on Fourth Avenue, there was the clinking of backgammon and chess. A man came around with hot coals for the bubbling water pipes, whose tobacco sweetened the air with flavors like citrus mist and grape and orange vanilla. Mohamed Ali,
title: SUMMER NIGHTS; Times of Celebration, Before and After a Daily Fast

body: Saying that a former New York police officer had breached the public's trust in a scheme to transport firearms and stolen merchandise, a federal judge sentenced him on Friday to nearly five years in prison. ''The offenses are indisputably serious, without any hint of justification,'' the judge, John G. Koeltl, said as the former officer, William
title: Ex-Police Officer Is Sentenced in Gun-Running Scheme

body: A boy who the police say was bludgeoned to death by his mother, three men cut down in a car by the spray of an assault rifle and a shop owner fatally shot in his store were among seven people killed in New York between Friday night and early Saturday. The police said the boy's mother called 911 from her apartment on Marcus Garvey Boulevard in
title: Violence Across New York Leaves 7 Dead

body: DUPPER--Marion, a beloved mother and special education teacher for the New York City Public School system for many years, died on Wednesday, July 4th, 2012, while residing in Boynton Beach, Florida. She was 87. Marion Elizabeth Gotimer was born in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, on December 19, 1924, in the family residence at 146-78 Street. She attended
title: Paid Notice: Deaths DUPPER, MARION

body: ON Wednesday morning, a short man walked up to a huge steel light pole in Riverbank State Park in Harlem and began punching away at it. The logo on the back of his warm-up jacket -- ''Johnny Knuckles, the Italian Steel Puncher'' -- suggested that this was not his first time doing this. So did the two discolored spots on the pole where the man's
title: CHARACTER STUDY; The Man Who Punches Steel

body: Around Town Weekend Parades (Sunday) Parade season is in full swing right now, with marchers taking to the streets to celebrate independence, cultural heritage and pride. One of three events on Sunday, the annual Celebrate Israel Parade -- formerly called the Salute to Israel -- will line Fifth Avenue, from 57th to 74th Streets, beginning at 11
title: Spare Times

body: One of the first lessons a Fontbonne girl learns is that no good can come from crossing Sister Dolores. Sister Dolores, the principal of Fontbonne Hall Academy, an all-girls Catholic high school in Brooklyn, once jumped out of her 2004 Toyota Corolla, confiscated a girl's beer, emptied it into the gutter, explained that as a certified alcohol
title: ON EDUCATION; Strict but Trusted, Nun Who Leads A School for Girls Is Irreplaceable

body: BAY RIDGE 2-BEDROOM $339,000 BROOKLYN: 307 72nd Street (Third Avenue), #2A A two-bedroom one-bath unit with a deck in a 1910 building converted in 1989 to a condop (a condo with separate residential and commercial units). Phyllis Stigliano, Aguayo & Huebener (516) 359-3332; ahrlty.com Open house Sunday, 12 to 1 p.m. COMMON CHARGE: $739.86 a month
title: On the Market

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Bartow-Pell Mansion Museum: Mansion and Garden Tours (Friday through Sunday) To celebrate Bronx Week, the museum will be offering free mansion and garden tours, beginning at 12:15 p.m. Also on view is ''Dibbles and Daisy Grubbers: The Art of the Garden Tool,'' an exhibition of familiar and unusual garden tools. The
title: Spare Times

body: It has long been pointed out that middle- and working-class voters are influenced by politicians pushing social issues to vote against their economic interests. Some progressives now seem to be elevating a social issue -- gay marriage -- over issues of economic justice. As important an issue as gay marriage may be, it is distressing to see the vote
title: REPLY ALL | LETTERS; When is a Flip Not a Flop?

body: ''We just said goodbye to our last 175,'' said Donna Taylor, principal of the Brooklyn School of Inquiry, referring to the 175 parents who toured her school in a single day -- the last of the 800 she had shown around the building in the days leading up to Friday, the deadline for families to apply to gifted and talented programs. But unlike the
title: SCHOOLBOOK; Top Score Isn't Enough for Preschooler Seeking Seat in Prime Gifted Programs

body: DOUGHERTY--James, Ph.D. of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. Devoted husband of the late Patricia Dougherty. Beloved father of Michael (Antonia), James (Danielle) and Edward. Loving grandfather of Faolan, Kara and Mia. Survived by many loving brothers, sisters, nieces and nephews. Former principal of Mandalay Elementary and South Woods Middle School. Director
title: Paid Notice: Deaths DOUGHERTY, JAMES

body: The United States Census Bureau, rebuffing a challenge by the Bloomberg administration, will not change its 2010 population total for New York City, a city official said on Sunday night. The city had argued last year that at least 50,000 residents of Brooklyn and Queens had been overlooked. The challenge centered on four neighborhoods -- Astoria
title: Census Numbers for City Won't Change, Bureau Says

body: WEINFLASH--Ruth Stupell, 80, of Cresskill, NJ died on March 27, at home with her husband and children at her side. Born on August 5, 1931, to Edward and Leah Stupell in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn; graduated from Connecticut College in 1952. Ruth was an actress, both by nature as well as by training having received accolades in her productions of Tennessee
title: Paid Notice: Deaths WEINFLASH, RUTH STUPELL

body: WEINFLASH--Ruth Stupell, 80, of Cresskill, NJ died on March 27, at home with her husband and children at her side. Born on August 5, 1931, to Edward and Leah Stupell in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn; graduated from Connecticut College in 1952. Ruth was an actress, both by nature as well as by training having received accolades in her productions of Tennessee
title: Paid Notice: Deaths WEINFLASH, RUTH STUPELL

body: There is no rest for the defenders of Italian-American dignity in the greater New York area. MTV's ''Jersey Shore'' may have finished its season, but on the horizon are TLC's ''Mama's Boys of the Bronx'' (April 9), about Arthur Avenue homeboys who live with their mothers, and A&E's ''Rambug'' (May 5), about ''a brawny group of hard-working,
title: TELEVISION REVIEW; Living Large and Falling Out in Deepest Brooklyn

body: IN 2010, Matt Green, 31, a former civil engineer, walked across the United States from Rockaway Beach, Queens, to Rockaway Beach, Ore. The journey took five months, during which he averaged 20 miles a day, pitched his tent on front lawns and wore through three pairs of Timberland Chocorua Trail boots. The plan was to take a break from the work
title: Leaving His Footprints on the City

body: Moments after Long Island University clinched its second consecutive N.C.A.A. tournament berth last week, the associate athletic director Greg Fox glanced toward press row. He spotted Richard Kurlander, the producer for the team's radio broadcasts, wearing his headset, tears streaming down his cheeks. For as long as Fox can remember, Kurlander has
title: Nothing Sweeter Than the Sound of a Bouncing Ball

body: She sang her usual repertory of tug-your-heartstring staples like ''Mother's Eyes,'' ''Jerusalem of Gold'' and ''Long Live the King.'' And after almost every song people flocked to the lip of the stage to hand Tamara Gverdtsiteli outsized bouquets wrapped in plastic. They moved their lips along with the lyrics. title: A Theater Tied by Heartstrings to the Old Country

author: Ruth Pennebaker's latest novel is ''Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakthrough.'' She blogs at geezersisters.com.
body: THE big white bus is leaving. If you're one of those ignorant souls who thinks New York City is limited to Manhattan and its cold, imperious skyscrapers, you should hop aboard. Paula Berkenstadt, today's guide for A Slice of Brooklyn Pizza Tour, is here to set you straight. Brooklyn is bigger and Brooklyn is better. You can't outtalk her, so you
title: THE OUT OF TOWNER; Brooklyn, in Thick And Thin (Crust)

body: Opening BACK FORTY WEST After closing Savoy last year, Peter Hoffman did not have to look far for a new concept for the space. He took the name of his East Village restaurant, Back Forty, and will borrow many of its dishes. The menu will have smoked items like pork shoulder, dinners to share featuring large meats like suckling pig, and
title: Off the Menu

body: Shaun O'Brien, one of the country's most celebrated character dancers, whose four vigorous decades with the New York City Ballet included more than 30 holiday seasons as Herr Drosselmeyer, the kindly eccentric at the heart of ''The Nutcracker,'' died on Thursday in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. He was 86 and had been retired from the company for merely 21
title: Shaun O'Brien, 86, Dancer Known for Character Roles

body: ALEXIS BITTAR stood in his studio in Dumbo, Brooklyn, surrounded by rows of chunky Lucite bangles in a spectrum of candy colors. The bracelets, which have graced the covers of nearly every major fashion magazine, including Vogue and Harper's Bazaar, have earned him many nicknames. ''He's the Lucite king,'' said Dawn Mello, a fashion consultant.
title: UP CLOSE; The Evolution of a Jewelry Prince
